Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was
What is your overall assessment of this course
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning
I received clear feedback that improved my learning
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was

Comments_List: A whole lot of human physiology, beyond the many courses I took in undergrad
I learned how different organ systems function, however the most interesting topics to me was how the different systems interact with each other.
I learned a lot about how the human body works. The grad lab was helpful in developing a deeper understanding of the topics and giving me a background in using MatLab.
Connecting structure and mechanism to larger functions

I gained a deeper understanding for human physiology as compared to my undergraduate physiology courses. The fact that this course is taught primarily by BME faculty offers an interesting perspective that I would have otherwise been ignorant to.
Knowledge of general human anatomy and physiology
how different systems in human body works
Learning to memorize a lot of information.
Physiology of cells, tissues, organs
A relatively deep understanding of the principle of physiology.
Comprehensive understanding and basic knowledge about various physiological systems in the body.
the knowledge of our body.
Reading, listening and speaking

The graduate labs were great, and very useful!

Some of the exams were a little unbalanced in terms of material covered. The second midterm shouldn't have had short answer parts which involved basically just rewriting the first part. The quizzes also took a shockingly long time to do.

Strengths - very thorough and I like that it taps into the expertise of many instructors
Weaknesses - I honestly cant stress enough that this class does not meet the needs of graduate students. Making us take a weed out undergrad class during our first semester just sucked (I mean I made it to grad school, I dont really see a need for further weed out classes), with quizzes that ate up hours out of each weekend (have you ever thought about having the quiz open on Monday and due on Friday instead of dominating my weekend?) and lab assignments that added to our workload. I can promise you without a doubt in my mind that my research suffered so that I could pass this class.

The learning objectives were very helpful in guiding us how to study for the exams. The graduate lab also helped reinforce a lot of the in-class concepts - hands-on work with certain topics made them easier to understand. The first graduate lab was a little disorganized, so it might be helpful to encourage students to download Matlab ahead of time.

The professors are very engaging and care a lot about our experience learning in the course. The grad lab was very helpful. The quizzes were too long. Writing so much for each short answer in order to receive full credit took multiple hours. Quizzes could contain some multiple choice and true false so they are more similar to exams. I would've also liked to use more math on exams and rely less on memorization. It would have been helpful for the correct answers for the practice exams to have been posted as well.

Strength- well organized 
Weakness- guest lectures seem a bit disconnected to the rest of the course in terms of expectations and learning objectives

I noticed throughout the course that many of the powerpoint presentations did not have figure legends/figure numbers that correspond to the book. This made it difficult to reference the book when I needed further clarification. 
The graduate discussion section was very helpful, but the fact that it takes place on Tuesday and often involves material that will not be covered until the end of the week makes it somewhat challenging. 
This course provides a phenomenal understanding of the renal system that I really appreciated.

Strength: General knowledge useful for any career focusing on human biology/physiology

Weakness: Weird emphasis on certain systems and ignoring other, more important systems. Why did we have 5-6 renal lectures and only half a lecture on the liver when even the instructors said it is both more important and more complex? 

The Tests were also poorly administered. There was a fair level of challenge in the actual questions, but it was ridiculous to not have an actual exam period for the two midterms. It really stinks, because the class was very good, and you could tell the instructors put a lot of time into it, but then it just appeared as if they didn't even try to make the exams an accurate assessment of student knowledge.
Some topics had different pace and depth. An extreme example is how reproductive systems was taught in just one lecture, whereas, some other systems took up to 6-7 lectures.
Graduate lab is interesting and it could be better if we can do other things instead of matlab
The material was intellectually challenging and interesting, but the amount of detail I needed to know seemed a bit irrelevant to my topic of study.
Reinstate extra credit for going to discussion section for grad students

Exams were too long. Expectations for some open response questions were somewhat unclear. Final exam would be better off being on the last third of the class only--way too much material to prepare for in my opinion.

Strength: A wide spectrum of knowledge. Weekly quiz helps reinforce what you learn. 
Weaknesses: Just like other biological courses, too many contents to memorize before exams. Though helpful, the weekly quiz prevents me from enjoying my weekends.

Strength: The course invited several professors from the school of medicine who could teach the course in a clinical-case-study way.

Weakness: Homework took too much time to complete.

Strengths: the combination of lectures, quiz, discussions and TF sessions is very helpful for students to understand the course.
Weaknesses: the final exam contains too much details which are hard to remember exactly.
I think the course should emphasize on main idea of physiology system rather than trivial details.

Too time consuming 
Very informative
Not unless you have to/its applicable to your research. I learned so much but the workload and expectations were insane.

I would recommend this course. At least for a graduate student, it is a great way to put some of your previous and current research into perspective in terms of understanding some of the intricacies of certain systems and how they all integrate together.
Yes. I think it is important to know human physiology for numerous regions. I learned a ton, but had to work very hard to memorize everything.
Yes. A great course for immersive learning of physiology

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. Having taken physiology as an undergrad, I feel like this class facilitated a deeper understanding that built on my more superficial knowledge from previous classes.
Yes. Physiology is important for research
I definitely learned a lot. I would not recommend unless the other classes being taken were as intensive as this class was.

I would recommend this course to students whose future study or work is heavily related to physiology (e.g. premedical students). However, I will not recommend this course to students who only needs a moderate level of knowledge in biology because the workload of course is quite high and most of the knowledge may not be necessary for them.
I would recommend this course to students in pre-Med track.

Yes. It can help the students whose major are biomedical related understand their study and research better. Although the workload of this course is a little too much, it endows students have a solid fundamental knowledge of physiology.
Yes. Informative
